title: Acute Calculous Cholecystitis
diagnosis_topic: Inflammation of the gallbladder secondary to cystic duct obstruction
setup_script: A 45-year-old woman presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain for the past 24 hours. She has fever and nausea. On physical exam, there is a positive Murphy’s sign. How would you proceed with this patient?

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 130/85 mmHg, HR 100 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 38.3 °C.
WBC 14,000/µL, mildly elevated AST/ALT and bilirubin; amylase and lipase normal.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders right upper quadrant ultrasound
dynamic_flow.reply: Gallbladder wall thickening >4 mm, pericholecystic fluid, gallstones obstructing the cystic duct.
CT confirms gallbladder wall thickening, distension, pericholecystic fluid, impacted cystic duct stone.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates NPO status, IV fluids, and analgesia
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient’s pain improves slightly; remains febrile and tender.
Coverage with ceftriaxone and metronidazole initiated.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays initiation of antibiotics
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient develops worsening fever to 39.1 °C, HR increases to 120 bpm.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults surgery and plans for early laparoscopic cholecystectomy
dynamic_flow.reply: OR scheduled within 24–72 hours of symptom onset.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays surgery beyond 1 week
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient develops worsening abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis; higher risk of conversion to open surgery.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident proposes percutaneous cholecystostomy in this otherwise healthy patient
dynamic_flow.reply: Examiner reply: “The patient is otherwise fit for surgery. What is your management plan?

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident indicates patient is critically ill or unstable and chooses percutaneous cholecystostomy
dynamic_flow.reply: Appropriate; patient stabilizes with drain in place.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident proceeds with laparoscopic cholecystectomy
dynamic_flow.reply: Gallbladder is inflamed with dense adhesions. Examiner: “Please describe your operative steps.
Shows patent common bile duct, no stones.
Patient recovers well, tolerates oral intake within 24 hours, discharged home on postoperative day 1.
Risk factors include female sex, obesity, pregnancy, rapid weight loss, oral contraceptive use.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of acute calculous cholecystitis via history, exam, and ultrasound
Initiation of resuscitation, NPO, antibiotics, and pain control
Appropriate and timely surgical intervention (early laparoscopic cholecystectomy)
Consideration of percutaneous drainage only in high-risk/unstable patients
Postoperative care and education on risk factors for recurrence

rubric.resident_feedback_template: Strengths:You demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by identifying acute cholecystitis and recognizing the need for surgical intervention. You communicated the management plan clearly and appropriately initiated resuscitation and antibiotics. Areas for Improvement:Work on clearly articulating the indications for percutaneous cholecystostomy in high-risk or unstable patients. Also ensure timely transition from diagnosis to definitive surgical management without unnecessary delays. Be prepared to describe operative steps of laparoscopic cholecystectomy in detail when asked.
